tit.cmt: elimated the kanji here as they are written again directly below

sen.j: 鎌倉公方（かまくらくぼう）とは、室町時代に室町幕府の征夷大将軍が関東十ヶ国における出先機関として設置した鎌倉府の長官。
sen.e: kamakura kubo (鎌倉公方) is the administrator of local agencies called 鎌倉府Kamakura Government, set up in ten provinces in Kanto region by 征夷大将軍Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians') of 室町幕府Muromachi bakufu in the 室町時代Muromachi Period.
sen.cmt: Kamakura Shogun / In the Muromachi period / local agencies across ten Kanto regions
sen.e: Kamakura kubo （鎌倉公方） was an administrator post in Kamakura prefecture which was established as an outpost position for the ten provinces of the Kanto region by the Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians) of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during the Muromachi Period.
sen.cmt: I had to make my own translation here, using the first one as a guide; eliminated kanji except for the title words
sen.e: Kamakura kubo was an administrator post in Kamakura Government which was established as an outpost position for the ten provinces of the Kanto region by the Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians) of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: （鎌倉公方） 削除用語統一

sen.e: It is also called 関東公方Kantokubo
The position was also referred to as the Kanto kubo.
sen.cmt: took out kanji; added more specific subject
sen.e: The position was also referred to as the Kanto kubo.

sen.j: 鎌倉公方はあくまでも歴史学用語及び鎌倉公方の自称であって当時の一般呼称ではない。
sen.e: The word kamakura kubo is absolutely a term of the historical science and the denomination used by kamakura kubo to call himself, and it was not a generally used term of that period.
Kamakura kubo is categorically a historical term which a Kamakura kubo used to call himself but was not used in general during that period.
Kamakura kubo is categorically a historical term which a Kamakura kubo used to call himself but was not used in general during that period.

sen.j: 当時の一般呼称は“鎌倉御所”か“鎌倉殿”である。
sen.e: The general names used for referring to this post was“鎌倉御所”"Kamakura Gosho," or“鎌倉殿” "Kamakura dono."
The one holding the post was generally referred to as "Kamakura Gonsho"or "Kamakura dono."
The one holding the post was generally referred to as "Kamakura Gonsho" or "Kamakura dono."

sen.j: また、鎌倉公方は将軍から任命される正式な幕府の役職ではなく、鎌倉を留守にしている将軍の代理に過ぎない。
sen.e: kamakura kubo was not an official position of government designated by the shogun, but was a mere acting position to Shogun during his absence in Kamakura.
Rather than being an official government position designated by the Shogun, a Kamakura kubo was no more than substitute position while the Shogun was absent from Kamakura.
sen.cmt: changed sentence structure to read more smoothly; acting→substitute;
sen.e: Rather than being an official government position designated by the Shogun, a Kamakura kubo was no more than substitute position while the Shogun was absent from Kamakura.

sen.j: 1349年に足利尊氏と弟の足利直義が対立（「観応の擾乱」に発展）した際、直義に代わって政務を執るために上京した足利義詮の後を継いで鎌倉に下向した足利基氏を初代とする。
sen.e: The first person who took the post was 足利基氏Motouji ASHIKAGA, who came down to Kamakura to succeed to the duties of 足利義詮Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, because足利尊氏 Takauji ASHIKAGA and his younger brother足利直義 Naoyoshi ASHIKAGA came to be opposed to each other (this conflict lead to 観応の擾乱 the Kanno Disturbance) in 1934, and Yoshiakira had to go back to Kyoto in order to administer 政務affairs of State in stead of Naoyoshi.

The first person to take the post was Motouji ASHIKAGA in 1349 who went to Kamakura to take over the duties of Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA when Yoshiakira had to return to Kyoto in order to administer affairs of state instead of Naoyoshi ASHIKAGA who had entered into conflict with Takauji ASHIKAGA, his older brother (this conflict lead to the "Kanno Disturbance").
sen.cmt: It was difficult to keep this as one sentence, but I tried to restructure it to read smoothly; took out kanji
sen.e: The first person to take the post was Motouji ASHIKAGA in 1349 who went to Kamakura to take over the duties of Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA when Yoshiakira had to return to Kyoto in order to administer affairs of state instead of Naoyoshi ASHIKAGA who had entered into conflict with Takauji ASHIKAGA, his older brother (this conflict lead to the 'Kanno Disturbance').

sen.j: 関東管領を補佐役として関東十ヶ国を支配した（後に陸奥国・出羽国も管轄した）が、代を重ねるに従って京都の幕府と対立するようになった。
sen.e: kamakura kubo (Motouji) controlled ten provinces in Kanto region (and later, he came to covered 陸奥国Mutu Province and 出羽国Dewa Province, as well) with 関東管領 Kanto kanryo (estate officer in Kanto region) as his assistant, but with each generation, the conflicting with 幕府bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in Kyoto became more serious.
sen.cmt: 関東管領→定訳不明： Kantokanryo (land manager in Kanto region)としました。
sen.e: As Kamakura kubo, Motouji controlled ten provinces in the Kanto region (later controlling Mutu Province and Dewa Province as well) along with the Kantokanryo (estate officer of Kanto）as his assistant, but with each generation conflict became more serious with the bakufu in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: eliminated kanji; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: As Kamakura kubo, Motouji controlled ten provinces in the Kanto region (later controlling Mutsu Province and Dewa Province as well) along with the Kantokanryo (estate officer of Kanto）as his assistant, but with each generation conflict became more serious with the bakufu in Kyoto.

sen.j: 永享の乱の際には関東管領とも対立し、第4代鎌倉公方足利持氏が敗れ、1439年に自害させられたことで一旦断絶した。
sen.e: When 永享の乱the Eikyo War broke out, he also came to have conflict with Kanto kanryo, and when the 4th kamakura kubo Mochiuji ASHIKAGA obliged Motouji to kill himself after his defeat in the war, this post had been discontinued for a while.

When the Eikyo War broke out, the Kamakura kubo entered into conflict with the Kantokanryo as well, and after losing the battle in 1439, the fourth Kamakura kubo Mochiuji ASHIKAGA was ordered to commit suicide leading to the post being temporarily discontinued.
sen.cmt: I changed the sentence here as the Japanese does not say that it was Motouji who was ordered to kill himself; he→the Kamakura kubo; restructured the sentence to read more smoothly; took out kanji
sen.e: When the Eikyo War broke out, the Kamakura kubo entered into conflict with the Kantokanryo as well, and after losing the battle in 1439, the fourth Kamakura kubo Mochiuji ASHIKAGA was defeated and ordered to commit suicide leading to the post being temporarily discontinued.

sen.j: 1447年に持氏の子足利成氏が幕府から鎌倉公方就任を許されて復活。
sen.e: In 1447, the post was recovered when Mochiuji's son 足利成氏Nariuji ASHIKAGA was allowed to take the post of kamakura kubo by the bakufu.
In 1447, the post was restored when Mochiuji's son Nariuji ASHIKAGA was allowed to take the post of Kamakura kubo by the bakufu.
In 1447, the post was restored when Mochiuji's son Nariuji ASHIKAGA was allowed to take the post of Kamakura kubo by the bakufu.

sen.j: 後に幕府と対立した成氏が、1455年に下総国古河市を本拠として「古河公方」と名乗るようになった（享徳の乱）。
sen.e: Nariuji, who had conflict with the bakufu, started to claim himself as「古河公方」 'Koga kubo,' setting his home base in 下総国古河市Koga country, Shimofusa Province.
sen.cmt: 下総国古河市→下総国古河郡：Koga Country, Shimofusa Proveinecとしました。
sen.e: Nariuji later came into conflict with the bakufu, and in 1455 moved his headquarters to Koga Country in Shimofusa Province and called himself the 'Koga kubo.'
sen.cmt: changed sentence to read more smoothly;
sen.e: Nariuji later came into conflict with the bakufu, and in 1455 moved his headquarters to Koga Country in Shimousa Province and called himself the 'Koga kubo' (Kyotoku War).
Remarks on the period tenure by name in chronological order.
Notes on the period of tenure by name in chronological order
Notes on the period of tenure by name in chronological order
The first kamakura kubo: Motouji ASHIKAGA 1349-1367.
The first Kamakura kubo: Motouji ASHIKAGA 1349-1367
The first Kamakura kubo: Motouji ASHIKAGA 1349-1367
The second kamakura kubo: Ujimitsu ASHIKAGA 1367-1398.
The second Kamakura kubo: Ujimitsu ASHIKAGA 1367-1398
The second Kamakura kubo: Ujimitsu ASHIKAGA 1367-1398
The third kamakura kubo: Kanemitsu ASHIKAGA 1398-1409
The third Kamakura kubo: Kanemitsu ASHIKAGA 1398-1409
The third Kamakura kubo: Mitsukane ASHIKAGA 1398-1409
The forth kamakura kubo: Mochiuji ASHIKAGA 1409-1439
The fourth Kamakura kubo: Mochiuji ASHIKAGA 1409-1439
The fourth Kamakura kubo: Mochiuji ASHIKAGA 1409-1439

sen.j: 五代足利成氏1449年～1455年1455年下総国古河に移り、古河公方となる
sen.e: The fifth kamakura kubo: Nariuji ASHIKAGA 1439-1455, in 1455 moved to Furukawa, Shimofusa Province and became Koga kubo.
The fifth Kamakura kubo: Nariuji ASHIKAGA 1439-1455; moved to Furukawa, Shimofusa Province in 1455 and became Koga kuba.
The fifth Kamakura kubo: Nariuji ASHIKAGA 1449-1455; moved to Furukawa, Shimousa Province in 1455 and became Koga kubo.
